results.title: You haven't changed a bit
results.creator_credit: Bruce Baker, Karl Holtsnider and Teleketics
results.brief_description: A dramatization about a young couple who after a quarrel take separate vacations at their respective parents’ homes. In the process they discover that despite their past associations their real identity lies in their relationship with each other.

results.title: You have to know that you like the job
results.creator_credit: David Haythornthwaite, Elisabeth Knight and Film Australia

results.title: You have struck a rock
results.brief_description: ‘You have touched a woman, you have struck a rock!’ was the cry in 1956 when 20,000 women occupied Union Buildings, the seat of the all-white South African government, to protest against the issuing of passes to black women. The film recreates this anti-apartheid womens’ campaign using a collage of rare photographs, newsreel footage and recent interviews with women involved.

results.title: You dust mite be next
results.creator_credit: Darlene Johnson, Chris Aronsten, Kate Reidl, Jane Keneally and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A docudrama about the evil little dust mite that plagues the world using up close and personal microscopic images, horror tales from victims and a biology lesson from experts Dr Ewan Tovey and Michael Morris.

results.title: You don't have to be mad
results.creator_credit: Greg Reading, Peter Johnson and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Discusses what sort of people a psychologist can help, and how they can help them, especially in the employment field. Uses light-hearted as well as serious examples. Cast includes Bruce Spence, Graeme Blundell. Assistant producer, Rosemary Gow; director, script, Greg Reading; photographers, John Hosking, Ross King; editor, Tom Foley; sound, Lloyd Carrick, Rod Simmons; commentator, Paul Ricketts.

results.title: You don't fool me
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Psychology”.
Shows how a social psychological experiment is designed, conducted and analysed. The experiment is a test to see if non-verbal behaviour gives clues as to whether a person is being deceptive - the hypothesis being that the face will not give clues to deception, but the hands and feet will. One of a series of a third level course from the Faculty of Social Science Open University. The purpose is to provide insight into social behaviour and experience. The essential focus is on theories, findings, and methods of social psychology.

results.title: You don't belong here [game trailer]
results.brief_description:
By staying true to your own ideals you will find a group of unique individuals where everyone belongs. A man is shipwrecked on a distant island. He must search the island for a tribe to live in by avoiding obstacles and collecting gems along the way. These tribes will take you in but on the condition you behave like them. You decline their offer saying you have a right to be yourself. You are then banished and must avoid members of these tribes as you continue your search. They attempt to catch you as you dont belong. Finally you come across a tribe that accepts you for who you are. They are all individuals and make you feel like you belong.

Under the category ‘Primary Videogames’, Liam Blake, Hope Valley, SA, was the Screen It 2012 winner.
